noun.description: A gesture, action, or sound that is used to convey information or instructions, typically by prearrangement between the parties concerned.
examples: the firing of the gun was the signal for a chain of beacons to be lit
the policeman raised his hand as a signal to stop

noun.description: An electrical impulse or radio wave transmitted or received.
An apparatus on a railroad, typically a colored light or a semaphore, giving indications to train engineers of whether or not the line is clear.

verb.description: Transmit information or instructions by means of a gesture, action, or sound.
examples: hold your fire until I signal

adjective.description: Striking in extent, seriousness, or importance; outstanding.
examples: he attacked the administration for its signal failure of leadership

origin: Early 17th century: from French signalé, from the Italian past participle segnalato distinguished, made illustrious, from segnale a signal.
